fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We need to show that \operatorname {wave}(Y, X) is a small set. Let Y^* be the functor sending a presheaf F to the set F(Y). The right Kan extension is given by \begin {aligned} Y_* (A)(B) &= \hom (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (B), Y_* (A)) \\ &= \hom (Y^* (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (B)), A) \\ &= \hom (\hom (Y, B), A) = A^{B^Y}. \end {aligned} Using the fact that \mathsf {Set} is total and cototal and writing \operatorname {¿} as the witness of cototality, we calculate \begin {aligned} \operatorname {wave}(Y, X) &= \hom _{\mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) \to \mathsf {Set}} (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?}, Y^*) \\ &= \hom _{\mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Set}} (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } Y_*, \textrm {Id}) \\ &= \hom _{\mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Set}} (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } Y_*, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (1^\textrm {op})) \\ &= \hom _{\mathsf {Set}} (1, \operatorname {¿}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } Y_*)) \\ &= \operatorname {¿}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } {Y_*}) \end {aligned} where the second equality is because the pseudofunctor (- \to \mathsf {Set}) preserves adjoint pairs. Hence we know this is a small set.

For a total category \mathcal {C}, we can define a functor \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathcal {C} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) that will serve as the double left adjoint of \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} iff the category is actually a totally distributive category. Since \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)(Y) = \hom (Y, X), we similarly define \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)(Y) = \operatorname {wave}(Y, X), and call the elements waves.

A wave w : Y \rightsquigarrow X is defined by a family of maps \hom (X, \operatorname {?} F) \to F(Y) natural in the presheaf F, where \operatorname {?} \dashv \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}. This is intuitively a categorification of the “way way below” relation Y \lll X in posets. If we take F = \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X), then we get an actual arrow \bar {w} : Y \to X. This defines a natural transform \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \to \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}, or equivalently \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \to \textrm {Id}.

We need to show that \operatorname {wave}(Y, X) is a small set. Let Y^* be the functor sending a presheaf F to the set F(Y). The right Kan extension is given by \begin {aligned} Y_* (A)(B) &= \hom (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (B), Y_* (A)) \\ &= \hom (Y^* (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (B)), A) \\ &= \hom (\hom (Y, B), A) = A^{B^Y}. \end {aligned} Using the fact that \mathsf {Set} is total and cototal and writing \operatorname {¿} as the witness of cototality, we calculate \begin {aligned} \operatorname {wave}(Y, X) &= \hom _{\mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) \to \mathsf {Set}} (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?}, Y^*) \\ &= \hom _{\mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Set}} (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } Y_*, \textrm {Id}) \\ &= \hom _{\mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Set}} (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } Y_*, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (1^\textrm {op})) \\ &= \hom _{\mathsf {Set}} (1, \operatorname {¿}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } Y_*)) \\ &= \operatorname {¿}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } {Y_*}) \end {aligned} where the second equality is because the pseudofunctor (- \to \mathsf {Set}) preserves adjoint pairs. Hence we know this is a small set.
The category of small sets \mathsf {Set} is a total category, and so is \mathsf {Set}^\textrm {op}.

The first claim is a special case of Example . For the second claim, we use the limit characterization of cototality. Given a functor F : \mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Set}, we need to show the existence of \lim (\pi _F : \int F \to \mathsf {Set}). We claim that this is a subset of \mathcal {P}(F(\mathcal {P}(1))), i.e. we need to show that all the other components of an element in the limit are determined by the F(\mathcal {P}(1)) component. This is true because \mathcal {P}(1) is a cogenerator of \mathsf {Set}.

Another way to see this is to let \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^\textrm {op} \dashv \operatorname {¿}, where \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^\textrm {op} : \mathsf {Set} \to (\mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Set})^\textrm {op} is the coyoneda embedding, and calculate \begin {aligned} \operatorname {¿}(F) &= \hom (1, \operatorname {¿}(F)) \\ &= \hom _{\mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Set}} (F, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (1^\textrm {op})) \\ &= \hom (F, \textrm {Id}). \end {aligned} So we only need to prove the natural transformations FX \to X form a small set, which works the same way, by substituting X by the powerset of 1.
